text:
i keep getting restarts of my web server

there just random restarts 


i have noticed my log always 
looks like this around when the restart happened .


[Sun Mar 09 14:48:44 2003] [error] [client x] Invalid method in request €L
[Sun Mar 09 14:48:44 2003] [error] [client x] Invalid method in request €L
[Sun Mar 09 14:48:44 2003] [error] [client x] Invalid method in request €L
[Sun Mar 09 14:50:35 2003] [notice] Parent: Received shutdown signal -- 
Shutting down the server.
[Sun Mar 09 14:50:35 2003] [notice] Child 1980: Exit event signaled. Child 
process is ending.
[Sun Mar 09 14:50:36 2003] [notice] Child 1980: Released the start mutex
[Sun Mar 09 14:50:37 2003] [notice] Child 1980: Waiting for 250 worker threads 
to exit.
[Sun Mar 09 14:50:37 2003] [notice] Child 1980: All worker threads have exited.
[Sun Mar 09 14:50:37 2003] [notice] Child 1980: Child process is exiting
[Sun Mar 09 14:50:37 2003] [notice] Parent: Child process exited successfully.



are there a way to prevent these request .
i notice there are always 


Invalid method in request €L


help !
creator: sales@teksigns.com
sales@teksigns.com
text:
Created attachment 5655
provide us your access.log contents for the time period between the invalid "

creator: wrowe@apache.org
text:
It appears this is either

   1. a bug in PHP.
   2. a very broken client.

  Note that the user with this condition;

166.82.79.38 - - [29/Mar/2003:18:23:20 -0500] "GET /shop HTTP/1.1" 301 237
166.82.79.38 - - [29/Mar/2003:18:23:20 -0500] "GET /shop/ HTTP/1.1" 200 607
166.82.79.38 - - [29/Mar/2003:18:23:21 -0500] "€L" 501 216
166.82.79.38 - - [29/Mar/2003:18:23:25 -0500] "€L" 501 216
166.82.79.38 - - [29/Mar/2003:18:23:26 -0500] "€L" 501 216

  appears to be a typical user navigating your pages, but either the user
  or apache ends up in an unstable state.  If this was a keepalive or a
  pipelined connection, there could be a significant bug in either php 
  or the client, but this doesn't correspond to any observed Apache bug.

  Adding the client header to your log file might help pin it down to either
  one or the other.

  In any case, we suggest you try the new php4 apache2handler module (which
  is different than the apache2filter module) or run PHP in cgi mode.

creator: nd@perlig.de
text: Isn't this the kind of requests that the openssl worm does?

creator: jorton@redhat.com
text: Any SSL connection to a non-SSL port gives a log entry like that.

creator: sales@teksigns.com
text:
i have the newest php installed 

it does not help 


i also have the apache2  dll
loaded from php .


apache still restarts .

creator: chip@force-elite.com
text:
Set OS to Windows

Is this a PHP specific bug?

Maybe send it over to their bug database
